Definition 
The returns of the disposition of any ray to be reflected 
I will call its fits of easy reflection, & those of its disposition 
to be transmitted its fits of easy transmission & the space 
it passes between every return, & the next return the intervals of 
its fits.
Prop. 18 2d Book.
“ If the Rays which paint the colours in the confines of yellow 
& orange pass perpendicularly out of any medium into Air, 
the intervals of their fits of easy reflection are the 1/89000 
part of an inch, & of the same length are the intervals of 
their fits of easy transmission &c.”
the next relates an experiment which is considered as 
a proof of the hypothesis as follows.
“The sun shining into my darkened chamber through 
a hole 1/3[?] of an inch wide, I let the intromitted beam of light 
fall perpendicularly upon a glass speculum ground concave 
on one side & convex on the other to a sphere of 6 feet 
& 1/2[?] of an inch & Quick silvered over on the convex side, & 
holding a white opaque chart at the distance of 6 feet from 
the Speculum in such manner that the beam of light 
might pass through a little hole made in the middle of 
the chart to the speculum & thence be reflected back to 
the same hole. I observed upon the chart four or five 
concentric Irises or Rings of colours like the Rainbow 
encompassing the hole, after the manner in which those 
appeared between the Object Glasses encompassing the black 
spot, but yet larger & fainter than those.
